column1: How do you feel?
column2: I like the style but it is a little tight in the waist.
column3: Here is the bigger size.
column4: This one fits me well but it is too expensive, can you make it a little cheaper?

column1: How was the party last night? Did you enjoy it?
column2: Oh, don ’ t talk to me about last night! It was the most awful evening I ’ Ve ever had.
column3: Why? What happened?
column4: Well. Mary had promised to be my date, but she stood me up. I waited for her for a full hour in the cold wind.
column5: What about the party?
column6: It was boring. The music was too slow and the food was lousy and, above all, I was really sick of the same old crowd all the time.

column2: Yeah me too. Oh! Can we stop at the shop really fast? I lost my makeup bag at the airport and I want to pick up a few things.
column3: Will you take long?
column4: No! Five minutes I promise!
column5: Come on! We have been here for almost an hour! I thought you said you were only going to get a few things! How long does it take you to pick out a lipstick and some nail polish!
column6: Are you crazy? You have no idea what you are talking about! Just for my eyes I have to get eye-liner, an eyelash curler, eye shadow, an eyebrow pencil and mascara. Then I need to get foundation, liquid foundation.
column7: Whoa whoa whoa! Are you nuts? How much is all this going to cost? I ’ m looking at the price at each one of these little things and it ’ s outrageous! This is basically a crayon!
column8: What about you? You spend as much or more money on your razors, after shave, cologne and gel! Not to mention how much you spend on clothes and...
column9: Fine! Get the stupid thirty dollar crayon!

column1: Would you like chicken or beef?
column2: Chicken, please.
column3: Here you are.
column4: Thank you. Oh, can I have another drink?
column5: Certainly. The service cart will be down the aisle again soon.

column1: Good morning, May. Good girl, you are reading English books again.
column2: Good morning. There is no reason to miss so beautiful a morning. Is that a new bird?
column3: Oh, yes, my daughter bought it yesterday. We call her Lulu.
column4: It looks so cute. Is it a parrot?
column5: Yes. Just look at her colorful feathers. What else can it be?
column6: I see. It's interesting that there is also a parrot in my English book. His mane is Polly.
column7: Really? A foreign parrot!
column8: He can speak English, too.
column9: Maybe you can teach Lulu some English words.
column10: Lulu. Lulu. Say hello. hello. Oh, she is so smart. Good bird.

column1: Charles, do you have any children ;
column2: Please visit t.cn.
column3: How many children do you have?
column4: I have two kids. A boy and a girl.
column5: What are their names?
column6: Jack and Stephanie.
column7: How old are they?
column8: Stephanie is 18 and Jack is 24.
column9: Are they in school?

column6: I suggest a walk over to the gym where we can play singsong and meet some of our friends.
column7: That's a good idea. I hear Mary and Sally often go there to play singsong. Perhaps we can make a foursome with them.
column8: Sounds great to me! If they are willing, we could ask them to go dancing with us. That is excellent exercise and fun, too.
column9: Good. Let's go now.
column10: All right.

column1: I want to find an old music box.
column2: We have a great selection. What decade are you looking for?
column3: Do you have anything made in the 1920s?
column4: We have six.
column5: Do any of them have dancing figures?
column6: Actually, two of them have dancing figures.
column7: That's fantastic. I think I like this one.
column8: A good choice. I prefer that one myself.

column10: Oh, no, I'm afraid not. These things are just too old to guarantee anything.
column11: I understand.
column12: Even if they break down, they're still works of art.

column1: Mom, my nose is bleeding.
column2: What happened, Peter? Did you have a fight?
column3: No, mom. I didn't.
column4: Did somebody hit you? Or did you just fall?
column5: Mom! I was just picking my nose, and now it's bleeding.

column1: Excuse me.Would you like a drink before your meal?

column7: Well, all the drinks including beer are free of charge.
column8: Are you sure? Then, I will have more beer, please.
column9: Don't worry.We will come back again a little later.

column1: I'll talk to you later.
column2: What's the rush?
column3: I have to get off the phone now.
column4: I'm not ready to get off the phone with you.
column5: There are other things I need to take care of.
column6: What is it that you need to do?
column7: Please don't be nosey.
column8: I'm not being nosey, it's just a question.
column9: You don't need to worry about that.
column10: That was mean to say.
column11: I am very sorry, but I must go.

column1: What is this for?
column2: It's the key for the safety deposit box.
column3: Okay, thanks.
column4: You're welcome, glad to be of assistance.

column1: Doesn't she have any friends?
column2: If she has, they must be fair-weather friends.
column3: Such friends are even worse than enemies.
column4: She'd better keep away from them.

column2: Yes. I've got a small room.
column3: How much is it?
column4: 200 yuan a week, but smoking is not allowed.
column5: OK.Can I see the room now?
column6: Would you mind waiting? I'm on the telephone.

column1: Welcome to Flower Power, sir. What can I get for you?
column2: I'd like a dozen long-stemmed roses.
column3: Would you like them delivered?
column4: Yes, I'd like them sent to this address.
column5: Do you want to sign the card?
column6: No, could you just write your secret admirer on it for me? I don't want her to recognize my handwriting.
column7: Ah... very well, sir. I'll have them delivered this afternoon.

column1: It's a lovely day, isn't it?

column9: That's nice. Having been here a little while surely gives you the advantage, eh?
column10: You bet. Now that you mentioned it, I think I'll call her now and see if she is available tonight.
column11: Good luck!
column12: Thanks!

column1: Do you know how late it is?

column3: I hope you don't think that excuse lets you off the hook.
column4: Not really. I'm telling the truth.
column5: Haven't I asked you to call if you're going to be home late?
column6: This is true, but it must've slipped my mind.
column7: Regardless, all you had to do was give a call.
column8: I know. I should've called.
column9: Come home late one more time, and you'll find your stuff outside.
column10: You want to throw me out over this?

I ’ Ve never seen anyone get so upset before. To make a long story short, it seems that Mr. Leo failed her because he caught her cheating.

column1: I am totally fed up with my boss. He has crossed the line one too many times with his sexist comments. This time I am really going to report him for sexual harassment.

column3: He constantly lets inappropriate things slip out, referring to the women employees as girls or calling us sweetheart or darling. I doubt any of my male colleagues would stand for such treatment.

column1: In 1986, a New Zealander Hackett popularized Bungee as a commercialized sport of mass entertainment. This sport is very challenging. It is a test of people's psychological ability of endurance. Especially when descending, as if they are watching a fast forward tape and when they bounce back, they sway around. The timid people will shrink back at the sight of it. Even if they jump off, they find it hard to avoid screaming with closed eyes. No wonder people give the title' brave' to anyone who jumps off.
column2: You see, the bungee participants take a deep breath when they stand at the starting spot and then, like diving, their heads are over heels and they jump off into the realm of the combination of heaven and earth. The wind roars at their ears and their bodies rapidly descend. They do not even have enough time to do several gymnastic movements and they are rebounded to the upper air by the cord.
column3: Entrusting life to the care of a rope indeed requires infinite courage.
column4: A young French fellow recalled his first bungee experience and said, " When I fastened the cord and walked to the platform, I was extremely nervous. When I looked down, I was nervous even more. If the cord had broken, I would be knocked to' bakemeat'. However, I knew my worries were unwanted. I was afraid if I retreated others might say something about me. I had to harden my heart and impose my head downward. I only felt wind wiring at my ears. My body rapidly descended. I thought that after only seven or eight seconds I was rebounded to upper air by the cord. In fact it was 30 seconds. Maybe because of my nervousness, I only felt seven or eight seconds. When rebounding to the high altitude, I felt a sudden sense of relief. I did not feel nervous very much, but very comfortable. "
column5: It is hard to come by in life that you experience this kind of' comfortable'

column1: Alright everyone settle down. Let ’ s get started.As you know, an important aspect of becoming a good citizen is understanding the genesis of our legal system. It is not enough to simply memorize our laws, it is necessary that we comprehend why and how they were formed. This brings me to our topic for today. Does anyone know what we celebrate on May first?
column2: Cinct de mayo?
column3: No, that ’ s May fifth in Spanish, James, no wonder you are failing my Spanish class. No, May first is International Workers ’ Day.
column4: Do we get a day off from school then?
column5: No! It is not considered to be a national holiday here in the US, but in other countries it is.
column6: Www, man!
column7: In the nineteenth century, working conditions were appalling, with workers being forced to work ten, twelve, and fourteen hours a day. Support for the eight-hour work day movement was growing rapidly, despite the indifference and hostility of many union leaders, and by April 1886, 250,000 workers were involved in the May Day movement. Previous legislative attempts to improve working conditions had failed, so labor organizers took drastic measures. They passed a resolution stating that eight hours would constitute a legal day ’ s work. And, on May First 1886, the resolution took effect.
column8: Cool! Is that why we only work eight hours now?
column9: Yes! But the happy ending came at a high price.On May third, 1886, police fired into a crowd of strikers at the McCormick Reaper Works Factory, killing four and wounding many. A mass meeting was called for the next day to protest the brutality.
column10: And then what happened?
column11: Well, as we say, the rest is history...

column1: I like chess better than xiangqi. And you?

column5: Correct! Another contrast is the rules for the general and the king. It seems the general or marshal in xiangqi is much too incompetent. They are required to stay in the palace, waiting to be checked and fleeing for life under the cover of the guards. Look at the king in chess, he is much more capable.
column6: Yeah, and though the king in chess doesn't have bodyguards, he has a queen who is the most powerful piece. I think this demonstrates the relatively higher social status of aristocratic women in medieval Europe than in China.
column7: There's another distinctive contrast. Both board games use a total of 32 pieces, but xiangqi is played on a 9 - by - 9 board, bigger than the 8 - by - 8 board used in chess.
column8: You mean, xiangqi pieces are allowed a larger space in which to move around?
column9: Sure. On a chessboard, fire is much more intensive. It has a smaller board, while those bigger pieces-chariots, horses and bishops-can cover longer distances.

column1: A Westerner said to his Chinese friend. “ Chinese people slurp when drinking soup. It ’ s disgusting. ” The Chinese friend replied, “ Westerners make a lot of noise licking their fingers when eating. It ’ s even worse. ”
column2: Everyone has his own habits, but these habits are not very good. The noise often spoils other people ’ s appetite.
column3: I attended a course on table manners while I was in the United States. Some of the things we learnt included how to place the napkin and utensils and how to pass the bread. Before each course, the teacher would ask if we wanted to learn the Continental European way or the American way. We always said “ American way. ” It ’ s amazing that everyone is so used to their own table manners. What is the Chinese way?
column4: The westerners use knives and forks to eat so it is complicated. The Chinese use a pair of chopsticks and eat out of the same plate. I assume it is less complicated, right?
column5: Not really. I did some research about Chinese table manners. The important rule is to remain silent while eating. Of course, this refers to family meals only. Not talking over meals is supposed to be good for the health. It is impolite if people do not talk to each other during a social party. The table arrangements and serving order for a social party are equally complicated. Each dish should be placed in the correct position. When fish is served, the tail should be pointing at the guest because tail meat is supposed to be tasty. If it is in winter, the stomach should face the right-hand side of the guest because that portion of the fish is very rich in winter. Each dish should be commenced by the eldest person who is seated at the head of the table. The diners should sit close to the table so food won ’ t drop on their cloths. No noise should be made when chewing. No one should move food back to the communal plate even if he doesn ’ t like it. One should drink soup slowly and is not supposed to make a lot of noise. All these table manners are very similar to Western habits.
column6: It seems that people share the same basic sense of etiquette regardless of their background. Apart from the different tools used for eating we seem to follow the same principles. We do not let inappropriate manners spoil other people ’ s appetite.Westerners like to say, “ bon appetite ” before meals which is one way to suggest “ mind your table manners. ” Is there such an expression in Chinese?
column7: Yes. We say “ eat well and drink well. ”

column1: Are the galaxies in the universe moving through space?
column2: No, the galaxies sit more or less passively in the space around them. But not too much. As the space between galaxies expands, it carries the galaxies further apart - like raisins in an expanding dough.
column3: But I heard that our Milky way galaxy may one day collide with a neighboring galaxy. If galaxies are moving apart from each other, how can they collide?
column4: Well, the universe is a chaotic place, and the gravity from one galaxy, or from a group of galaxies, may disturb the motion of its near neighbors, causing them to collide. However, on average, when you compare two large enough chunks of space, the galaxies in one are moving away from the galaxies in the other.

Look at China, for example, they have 1.4 billion people, half a billion of whom have recently entered the middle class. Here alone the aggregate demand for consumer goods represents an amazing wealth generating opportunity.

But the cafeteria is doing its best to force me to be a vegetarian. They have been serving the Chinese cabbage and white gorse for three days. Haven ’ t you noticed that?

column1: Hi, did you call for an exterminator?

We will have to cover the entire house and fumigate it. Unfortunately that means you will have to find a place to stay for the next three days.

column1: Well, how did you enjoy your seaside trip?
column2: It was funny.
column3: Tell me about it, will you?

column1: Look at these clothes designed by top fashion designer like Versacci, Calvin Klein, and Vivienne Westwood. What do you think of them?
column2: Well, they look lovely, but they ’ re not very practical. I mean, would you wear that dress to the office or walking down the street?
column3: I know what you mean. People would stare at you in amazement if you wore something like that in an everyday situation. I suppose only extravagant rich people wear them at cocktail parties.
column4: Maybe. I ’ m not sure why they have fashion shows like this. Hardly anyone will buy those clothes. The clothes you see are nothing like the ones that ordinary people wear. It seems like a waste of money.
column5: I think that the designers hold these fashion shows for a few reasons. First, it ’ s just like a big party. They can meet each other and network. The other thing is that it is great advertising. All the journalists and photographers are there. Thirdly, it give them a chance to show what they would like to see people wearing.
column6: You meant it ’ s an expression of their fantasies?
column7: Yes. I think the designers are saying that these clothes are what they would like to see people wear if those people weren ’ t concerned with what other people might think. In a way, the designers are saying ‘ don ’ t worry about what others think. Wear what you like! ’.
column8: Very philosophical. I think they design these clothes more for publicity. They try to see who can be the most extreme and outrageous, but still stylish.
column9: Come on. All this fashion has reminded me that I want to buy some clothes.

column1: A funny thing happened to me the other day.
column2: Oh, yes?
column3: I was just thinking about someone I went to school with, this boy I was quite friendly with in third grade. We used to hang out together - he lived next door - but then my parents moved and I changed schools and never saw him again.
column4: Mmm.
column5: Well, I was walking down Nan Jing Dong Lu ( Nan-Jing E. Rd. ) during my lunch break thinking about this boy-I have no idea why I was thinking about him.
column6: Really?
column7: Yes. And suddenly I heard someone call my name. I turned around and there was this man looking at me. I didn't recognize him at all, but he obviously knew who I was.
column8: Oh, yeah, that's embarrassing when that happens.
column9: You got it. Well, he walked up to me and said my name again and then I realized it was the boy I had been thinking about, the one from third grade!

column1: Is the environment a big issues in your country? It is in mine.

column3: What methods do you use to conserve water?
column4: Water is rationed. We can only use a certain amount each month. It means that we cannot use some modern household items, like washing machines. They use too much water.
column5: I see. I think the biggest environment problem in my country is air pollution.
column6: Yes, I agree. The air here is much more polluted than in my country. Of course, my country is more agricultural and has much less industry.
column7: We have reduced emission of air pollutants in recent years, but cars are still a major source of them. Factories have become cleaner as stricter environment pollution law have been introduced.
column8: The problem is now on a truly global scale. I don ’ t believe that any single country can do anything about it.
column9: I think you ’ re right. There needs to be an international response to this problem.

column1: Do you like cooking?

column1: I ’ m thinking about getting a pet, but I ’ m really not sure which animal would be suitable. Could you give me some advice?
column2: Certainly! The first thing is to be honest about how much time for you can devote to your pet. Dogs are very demanding. You need to take them for walks and they love to play. Cats, on the other hand, are more independent.
column3: I ’ m fairly busy, so I really need an animal that I don ’ t need to care of very much. Actually, I ’ d like a pet that ’ s a little unusual. I don't ’ really want a typical pet, like a cat, dog, or hamster. Do you have any suggestions?
column4: Unusual pet are often more expensive to keep. Is that a problem?
column5: Not really. By the way, I don ’ t want a pet that could be dangerous, like a tarantula or rattlesnake.
column6: We have those, but I only sell them to people I know well, for obvious reasons. How about a lizard? I have some that are very brightly coloured, are not aggressive, and are easy to feed and look after.
column7: That sounds ideal. Could you show me some?
column8: Sure. Come over here. As you can see, I have a wide selection of species. They can live together, if you want lizards of different kinds. Do you have a favourite colour?
column9: I like the red one. What do they eat?
column10: You can feed them on various things. They will eat small pieces of meat, but I ’ d recommend insects. You can get them from your garden, but remember that lizards eat a lot insects. I sell them here.
column11: Thanks a lot. What I ’ ll do si find out more online and drop by next week.
column12: That ’ s fine. You shouldn ’ t make a hasty decision when choosing a pet.

column4: Well, as for Albert, he should go to an office supply store.There' s a very good one called Office Depot. They have everything he will need.And their prices are good too. It's very convey
